subject: Re: [junit] Help,what's wrong with my TDD practice in my daily life?
msgSnippet: Hi CÃ©dric, ... I disagree. When I ve found something difficult to write test first I ve always done a spike, then delete the code and rewrote it test first.

Subject: Re: [junit] Help,what's wrong with my TDD practice in my daily life?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=220833585; y=Y6brXXegkW3C2TcDz-Txe-CDnBLQ8e7kVyYXEoOjl2O6aNz8e0EbpPQbesk

Hi C=E9dric,

On 9/10/07, you wrote:
>
>  Just like everything else, use TD=
D sparingly.  I understand you are
>  currently doing this as an exercise, =
so it's healthy to take it to
>  extremes and do everything by the book in =
order to learn, but in your
>  real work, use your judgment and decide for =
yourself when you are
>  indeed writing too much code, in which case it's p=
robably safer to go
>  the usual route (get your code to work, then write t=
ests for it).
>
>  The downside of TDD is that you can end up writing a lot=
 of tests for
>  business code that you quickly throw away and rewrite, so =
the amount
>  of churn can be quite high.
>

I disagree. When I've found so=
mething difficult to write test first
I've always done a spike, then delete=
 the code and rewrote it test
first. I've always found the result to be a l=
ot more cleaner,
especially since I wind up cleaning up the code anyway whe=
n I used to
write tests around them.

I'd rather have my business code test=
ed rather than not test it under
the assumption it will one day be thrown a=
way. ;)

Thanks,
James
